title: Steelers offense a mixed bag in joint practice with Bucs; run game ‘sloppy’
description: With Aaron Rodgers possibly sitting out all three preseason games, Thursday might have been the best chance to evaluate the QB this summer.
content:
PITTSBURGH — The 2-yard line is where every Steelers practice begins, with Mike Tomlin’s classic Seven Shots drill. Thursday’s joint practice with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers was no different.

“I think we won like 7-0 or 6-1, something like that,” tight end Pat Freiermuth said. “It was a great showing. I thought we built on that as well throughout the rest of the practice.”

Tomlin said that quarterback Aaron Rodgers won’t play in Saturday’s preseason game and has hinted that the veteran may not play at all in the exhibition games. That made the joint practice one of the most game-like environments to evaluate the quarterback against an opposing defense that isn’t the league’s highest-paid. Unfortunately, Steelers policies prohibit media members from reporting anything they “see and hear” in settings that aren’t open to fans, which significantly limits the level of detail that can be provided to fans hungry for intel. However, interviews with players confirmed Thursday was a mixed bag for the first-team offense.

“There are some things that you’re going to want to clean up, like every day out here,” Freiermuth said. “But for the most part, I thought it was solid.”

While the start of practice was promising, the day ended with an unsuccessful two-minute drill. Freiermuth confirmed the Steelers failed to record a first down during the sequence. Throughout camp, the Steelers had a number of two-minute drills fizzle, including during the Friday Night Lights practice when they failed to pick up a first down. Their best performance to date came on one of the final practices of camp, when they drove into the red zone to put themselves in position to kick a “game-winning” field goal.

“Obviously, with the game on the line, the offense wants to go out there and capitalize,” Freiermuth said. “There’s going to be stuff that we need to figure out on that. But (we have) a lot of confidence. It’s earlier in the process, and so we’ll watch film and get it down.”

Thursday’s success during Seven Shots and the shortcomings in the two-minute drill mirror camp. Rodgers’ ability to fit the ball into tight windows should provide a level of confidence that they can be efficient in the red zone. However, situational football is still a work in progress.

The Steelers have more than three weeks before their first game. The more time Rodgers has to build a connection with his new receiving corps, the better things should look. The question is: Will the Steelers add another target before the season?

“We always do our due diligence,” assistant GM Andy Weidl said. “That’s our job. Any player that becomes available at any position in the league, that’s on us. We have to know the player. If it’s right player, right price, you look at it.”

Often in camp, the Steelers offense had little room to run against the bolstered defensive front. Thursday presented a different kind of challenge. With Buccaneers veteran Vita Vea in the middle of a four-down front — to go along with 2023 first-round pick Calijah Kancey and edge rusher Yaya Diaby — the Buccaneers allowed the fourth-fewest rushing yards per game (97.8) and the ninth-fewest yards per carry (4.3) last year. They added free-agent edge rusher Haason Reddick to the mix this offseason.

Based on center Zach Frazier’s assessment, there’s still plenty of room for improvement.

“They brought a lot of blitzes and pressures and stuff today,” Frazier said. “Today, we were a little sloppy. I feel like we can definitely clean it up. I feel like it’ll definitely even be cleaned up for the game.”

Offensive coordinator Arthur Smith has joked that the Steelers didn’t sign receiver DK Metcalf and Rodgers to “run the wishbone.” A more balanced attack could be on the horizon. That said, the Steelers still want to be a team that uses the run game to take pressure off Rodgers’ right arm and create off play-action.

“I think every day they go out there together, they get better,” Weidl said before the practice. “I think they have the right mindset. If you watch these guys in practice, they come off the field in team (periods), they start running wind sprints. It’s a culture that they’re developing.

“As a young group, you want to watch them grow together. … As those guys come up and they gain that experience, they work together, it’s only going to serve them well and serve our team well.”

As early as Joey Porter Jr.’s rookie year, he often was tasked with shadowing the opponent’s top receiving threat. But when the Steelers revamped their secondary, they added two more alphas — Ramsey and Darius Slay — who built their resumes by shutting down WR1s. Ahead of the Steelers’ joint practice, there was no debate about who would get Evans.

“Jalen is going to get it,” Tomlin said before practice. “Some people may hate it, and I love that competitive spirit in the collective, but I think it’s already been decided.”

Buccaneers rookie receiver Emeka Egbuka said that Ramsey defended him at times and that the Steelers played more zone coverage than man, which means that Ramsey didn’t take every rep against Evans. However, Egbuka said Evans got the last word with a touchdown during the Buccaneers’ two-minute sequence.

“Those are two All-Pros, two guys competing, wanting to be the best and wanting to get better,” Buccaneers coach Todd Bowles said. “Just as hungry as Jalen is, Mike is as well. So it was a good battle. It was good, friendly competition. Obviously, you got to see the tape. There were no winners. It was just good work.”

Overall, the Steelers defense has often been dominant against the first-team offense in camp. Based on Brandin Echols’ assessment, the Buccaneers were more successful, especially early. Egbuka said the Bucs offense won Seven Shots 4-3.

“We just didn’t come out with the energy,” Echols said. “We came out a little flatter than usual. We’ve just got to fix that.”

Tomlin rules out several veterans for Saturday

Tomlin said that the Steelers plan to approach Saturday’s preseason game “very much like the last one,” when about 20 players rested. He’s already ruled out the following players: QB Rodgers, WR Metcalf, RB Jaylen Warren, TE Freiermuth, TE Jonnu Smith, LG Isaac Seumalo, OLB T.J. Watt, OLB Alex Highsmith, DT Cam Heyward, ILB Patrick Queen, Slay, Ramsey and Porter. Calvin Austin III is still recovering from an abdominal injury, and rookie Yahya Black was spotted with a large wrap on his right elbow during the final training camp practice.
summary: The Pittsburgh Steelers had a mixed performance in a joint practice with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, with the team winning 7-0 or 6-1, according to tight end Pat Freiermuth. However, the team's run game was described as sloppy by center Zach Frazier as a point of improvement. The team's quarterback, Aaron Rodgers, will not play in the upcoming preseason game and may not play at all in the exhibition games. The joint practice was one of the most game-like environments to evaluate the quarterback against an opposing defense, as Steelers policies prohibit media from reporting anything seen in settings that aren't open to fans. The Steelers failed to record a first down during an unsuccessful two-minute drill, which they have seen throughout camp. Assistant GM Andy Weidl and offensive coordinator Arthur Smith have been discussing the possibility of adding another player before the season.
shortSummary: The Steelers' joint practice with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers was a mixed bag, with promising performances but notable failures, and ongoing player evaluation.
argos_summary: During a joint practice with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, the Pittsburgh Steelers showcased mixed results, excelling in the Seven Shots drill but struggling in a two-minute drill. Head coach Mike Tomlin confirmed that quarterback Aaron Rodgers will not play in the upcoming preseason game, and several key players have been ruled out. The Steelers' offense is still developing, particularly in situational football, while the defense has shown dominance throughout training camp.
